content: been a while since we've done a clip-on feature for our little dungeon tile so
let's do that and you'll see that actually even though
we're doing a throne you could attach anything to this Dyess so let's get to
it let's start with double corrugated
cardboard cut one piece that is two and a half inches by two and three
sixteenths of an inch and cut another one that is two inches by one and
fifteen sixteenths of an inch then cut two chipboard rectangles each of them
two and a half by two inches and finally another rectangle of double corrugated
cardboard that is two and a half by one and a half inches on the first two
pieces apply corrugation cladding to three sides only making sure that one of
the long sides is the unfinished one then hot glue them together as shown
with the exposed edges flush then hot glue those exposed edges to one
of the chipboard pieces so that they're flush at the bottom as shown
then hot glue the remaining cardboard piece to the chipboard and complete the
sandwich with the last piece of chipboard so this all forms a half inch
tall clip which is a technique we've used many times before on this channel
apply corrugation cladding to that as well and black bomb the entire assembly
now get some thin cardstock such as a manila folder and cut a strip about one
and a quarter inch wide fold it and fit it to the steps as you see here and then
cut off the excess paint it with a bold color while that's drying sponge on your
usual dark gray and then light gray to the entire assembly
then I just added some white lines along each edge of the carpet and hot glued it
onto the assembly make the throne itself from dollar-store foam board what you're
seeing here is kind of self-explanatory so I'm not going to get bogged down in
dimensions to rectangles to make the sides a rectangle in the middle for the
seat and some kind of shape for the backrest I just did a simple point here
attach it all with hot glue and black bomb it while that's drying I'm going to
go ahead and glue a couple beads to the main piece to torch holders along the
wall and two decorative beads at the edge of the Dyess so back to the throne
I covered the edges with metallic gold and then to get a nice marble look I
applied solid green to the seat and then immediately swirled in some solid black
don't overwork this or it'll start to actually mix which is kind of what
happened a little bit here for a marbled look you don't want that finally hot
glue the throne onto the carpet and adorned with some torches
so here it is in context being used as a clip-on to hold two tiles together then
not much more to say about it than that so I am why lock thank you for joining
me and I'll see you next time
